_prev_prog_3.Description: The prevention program applies to all operations within the covered process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
EQUALIZER MIDWEST, INC.
HASTINGS, NEBRASKA


Equalizer Midwest, Inc. (a wholly-owned subsidiary of Equalizer, Inc.) owns and operates a fertilizer facility near Hastings, Nebraska which is subject to the Environmental Protection Agency?s Risk Management Program rule under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.  

The Risk Management Program rule requires a facility which handles threshold amounts of certain chemical substances to develop a program (if one is not already in existence) to prevent accidental releases of these substances and to minimize the consequences of those releases that do occur.  This Risk Management Program is to include a management system, a hazard assessment to identify the possible offsite impacts of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios, a five-year accident history record, an accidental release prevention program, an emergency response program and a Risk Management Plan which summarizes the entire program and is submitted to the EPA.

The following is the Executive Summary of the Risk Management Plan for the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility located near Hastings in south central Nebraska, serves as a storage and distribution terminal for fertilizer products.  

The Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility serves as a vital link in the fertilizer distribution system by receiving products from manufacturing plants, by storing the products until they are needed and by distributing the products primarily in the area of south central and southwestern Nebraska.  Being centrally located, the facility provides a convenient location for fertilizer retailers to get their product.  Additionally, Equalizer Midwest, Inc. is committed to being a solid, reliable member of the Hastings community.  

Equalizer Midwest, Inc. has 12 full-time employees, with a total of more than 100 years of combined operating experience.  Although not large in number, thes

e employees make a big impact on the community in which they live.  They can be found on the Agri-Business Subcommittee of the Hastings Chamber of Commerce, on the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee and are involved in area youth activities.  The employees recognize that community involvement and volunteerism are the most effective way to improve the communities they live in.

Anhydrous ammonia is the only regulated substance handled at the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility that is subject to the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule.  The anhydrous ammonia is primarily received by rail and shipped by truck and is stored as a refrigerated liquid at ambient pressure and also as a liquid under pressure.  A refrigeration system is utilized in support of the storage of the liquid at ambient pressure and various vessels and piping serve in the transfer of ammonia within the process.   Ammonia heaters are utilized to raise the temperature of the refrigerated liquid from   -28 degrees F to 35 degrees F, as required for the loading of ammonia transports.  The anhydrous ammonia distributed from this facility is used almost exclusively as an agricultural fertilizer.

The facility was originally designed and constructed to be an anhydrous ammonia manufacturing plant and was operated as such from startup in 1962 until 1985, at which time the manufacturing process was discontinued.  Since 1985, the facility has functioned strictly as a terminal for anhydrous ammonia, utilizing the storage and transfer infrastructure of the original manufacturing plant.  Also, since 1985, changes including additions and improvements have resulted in the current design and operation of the terminal.  Farmland Industries, Inc. owned and operated the facility from 1962 until 2003.  In June of 2003, the facility was purchased by Equalizer, Inc. of Waco, Texas, which subsequently established the ownership and operation of the facility under Equalizer Midwest, Inc.

Accidental Re

lease Prevention and Emergency Response 

It is the policy of Equalizer Midwest, Inc. to eliminate significant accidental releases of any substance and, particularly, of any hazardous or regulated substance and to minimize and eliminate to the extent possible even minor and inconsequential releases of any type.  Prevention of accidental releases is critical to the safe operation of the facility, to the safety of its employees and to the safety of the general public.  Consequently, the management and employees of the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases from this facility.

The Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility has a written Emergency Response Plan - as required by the RMProgram and other EPA and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rules - and is committed to implement the plan in response to any accidental release to minimize the impact to employees, the community and the environment.  The response plan is coordinated with the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the local emergency response agencies.   Personnel have interacted with these agencies for many years regarding activities at the facility and emergency response issues.

Employees are trained in the implementation of the plan and appropriate response activities that could be required in the event of an emergency.

Prevention Program

As a handler of anhydrous ammonia, the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule, 29CFR 1910.119, in addition to the RMProgram rule.  Under the RMProgram rule, the handling of ammonia at the facility is characterized as a Program 3 process, requiring a Program 3 Prevention Program.  For a facility with a Program 3 process, the Prevention Program required under the RMProgram rule is identical to that required by the OSHA PSM standard.

The OSHA Process Safety Management/EPA RMP Prevention Program consists of a set of management policies and procedures

which promotes and recognizes process safety and the prevention of accidents in facilities that handle, use, store and process hazardous substances.  The procedures address all aspects of facility activities including training, maintenance, operating procedures, process reviews, the maintenance and updating of critical process information, safe work practices, incident investigation, safety audits and other activities in a manner to provide controls to prevent errors, failures and inadvertent changes in a process that could result in accidents.

The Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility adheres to the requirements of PSM and has adopted Farmland?s written policies and procedures addressing all aspects of the PSM and RMP Prevention Program requirements.  Specific features of the Accidental Release Prevention Program include personnel on-site 24 hr/day - 365 day/yr, visual inspection of process equipment as part of the daily routine, continuous monitoring of storage and transfer conditions, alarm systems to indicate operating conditions outside the norm, automatic shutdown of ammonia transfer when control parameters fall outside a specified range and manual remote shutdown of ammonia transfer - as needed, refrigeration system for ammonia storage, safety relief valves on all lines and vessels, flare in continuous operation, level indicators on all storage vessels, daily operating logs with inventory records, inspection program for all ammonia storage tanks, bullets, vessels and piping and monthly safety meetings.

Equalizer Midwest, Inc. is committed to adhering to and maintaining the Accidental Release Prevention Program.

Emergency Response Program

Equalizer Midwest, Inc. has adopted both Farmland?s written Emergency Response Program and written Emergency Response Plan, until such time as operating conditions warrant revision.  The Plan is coordinated with the community emergency response plan and is available to the local emergency response agencies.  Emergency Planning

and Community Right-to Know information, as required under SARA Title III, has been provided to the Nebraska State Emergency Response Commission, the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the local jurisdictional fire departments.

Equalizer Midwest, Inc. is an active participant in the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee and interacts with various local agencies - such as fire departments, law enforcement departments and emergency medical providers - in its emergency planning.

Employees receive annual training in the facility?s Emergency Response Plan and also
receive various additional safety training, both in general, and in the competencies relative to their required roles in the emergency response plan

Five-year Accident History

The RMProgram rule requires inclusion of the five-year accident history of the facility for all accidental releases of regulated substances that resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

Farmland Industries, Inc. had an excellent five-year accident record, at this location, with no RMProgram reportable releases.  It is expected that the safe operating record will be maintained under the management of Equalizer Midwest, Inc.

Hazard Assessment

The hazard assessment element of the RMProgram rule requires the evaluation of potential offsite effects of ?worst-case? and ?alternative? release scenarios of regulated substances.

The EPA has defined a worst-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint.  The EPA does not allow active mitigation measures to be considered in the worst-case release scenario analysis.  The impact of the potential release must be quantified in accordance with the release criteria dictated in the rule.  The projected impact distanc

e must be determined using EPA defined atmospheric conditions and is intended to provide a conservative estimate of the maximum possible area that might be effected.  According to the EPA, the worst-case scenario is intended to ensure that no potential risks to public health are overlooked but that the distance to an endpoint estimated under the worst-case scenario should not be considered a ?public danger zone?.
Possible causes or the improbability that such a release may occur are not considered.

EPA has defined the alternative release scenario as a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case release; however, as with the worst-case, the alternative release improbability is not taken into consideration.

As previously mentioned, anhydrous ammonia is the only regulated substance handled at the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility that is subject to the RMProgram rule and, therefore, to the requirements for hazard assessment.

Worst-case Release Scenario - Anhydrous Ammonia

Owing to the seasonal nature of the use of anhydrous ammonia as an agricultural fertilizer, to the limited rate at which this product can be received and to the fact that the demand for this product during the ?season? can be very great over a relatively short time span, an inventory of anhydrous ammonia must be available at the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility for when it is needed.

The largest vessels at the facility for the storage of anhydrous ammonia are the refrigerated liquid storage tanks within which the liquid ammonia is maintained at ambient pressure.  Therefore, the hypothetical worst-case release scenario for this location is assumed to involve the catastrophic failure of one of these tanks.  And, as required by the rule, the worst-case release scenario also assumes that the entire storage tank content is released as a gas in 10 minutes.  The distance to the endpoint for this unlikely worst-case release scenario was obtained using the EPA?s RMP*Comp Version 1.06.

This hy

pothetical worst-case release scenario, as dictated by the rule, is considered to be extremely unlikely to occur for many reasons.  In addition to the stringent design controls for this type of vessel, facility maintenance and inspection programs address the integrity of the process and storage tanks, including these, and largely preclude such an unlikely failure.

Alternative Release Scenario - Anhydrous Ammonia

A more reasonably likely release event than the worst-case scenario, but which is still hypothetical, can be envisioned as occurring in the facility areas where anhydrous ammonia is handled regularly, e.g. in the loading and unloading areas.  Since the RMProgram rule does not require the use of a catastrophic vessel failure for the alternative release scenario and since the rule does allow for the consideration of active mitigation measures such as system shutdown safeguards (which are located throughout the facility) and operator intervention to mitigate and limit the consequences of an accidental release, the release rates and total release amounts for alternative release scenarios are generally significantly lower than those of worst-case release scenarios.  Thus, the alternative release scenario could include such an event as an ammonia transfer line or hose failure, the lifting of a safety relief valve, a seal failure on an ammonia transfer pump or etc.

The hypothetical alternative release scenario for the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility is assumed to involve a break in a four inch ammonia transfer line.  The distance to the endpoint for this release was determined with the DEGADIS model, i.e. a publicly available model which is known to provide reasonable estimates of concentrations and distances associated with ammonia release events.  The impact of this release scenario is predicted to extend offsite.

Planned Changes for Safety Improvements

Safety improvements occur as part of an ongoing evaluation process at the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facilit

y and are facilitated by the Process Safety Management/Prevention Program.  In a formal procedure, at least every five years, the process hazard analysis is updated and revalidated, but review is also ongoing through management of change procedures, operator training, incident investigation and mechanical integrity programs.  As a result, changes relevant to safety occur continuously as needs are identified through these procedures and policies.
